(40) 293rdConclusions,Minute 2.)The Prime Minister informed the War Cabinet that he had invited the Chiefs of Staff to consider whether we could now affordsome further assistance to Greece, more particularly by reinforcingour air detachment in that country.The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that the GreekMinister was coming to see him that afternoon. He proposed toinform him that recent telegrams from Greece were under examina-tion; that we appreciated the strength of the Greek case, and would do what we could to help them.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.Production. 2. In a general discussion the view was expressed, and metArrangements with general agreement, that on the next occasion when there was afor Parlia- debate in the House of Commons on production questions, the debatementary debate, should last for two days. This would give better scope for an effective reply than was possible in a single day's Debate, with thepresent short sittings.Excess Profits It was also suggested that the present arrangements in regardTax. to the Excess Profits Tax, which in many cases left no incentive, ledto some slackness and waste of expenditure.The Chancellor of the Exchequer, who said that he had had thismatter under consideration, was invited to consider the matter further and bring proposals before the War Cabinet, say, in a week's time, with a view to effecting such modifications in the present arrangements as would introduce a measure of incentive.The War Cabinet took note of this discussion.Great George Street, S.W. 1,January 7, 1941.
